9134 S1381-1169(14)00244-1 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.05.034 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 X-ray diffraction patterns of TiO2–CeO2 supports (a) and Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts (b) (○: anatase phase in TiO2; ●: rutile phase in TiO2; ▵: CeO2; ▴: Ce2O3; ■: Ce6O11). Fig. 2 CO DRIFT spectra of Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 3 X-ray photoelectron spectra of Ti 2p (a), Ce 3d (b) and O 1s (c) in Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 4 X-ray photoelectron spectra of Cu 2p (a) and Pd 3d (b) in Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts. Fig. 5 Bright field HRTEM images of PCTC1 with low-magnification (a) and high-magnification (b, c) mode. Tel.: +82 2 3290 3299; fax: +82 2 926 6102. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 2 3290 3727; fax: +82 2 926 6102. Graphical abstract Pd–Cu supported on TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxides (Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2) were tested for the reduction of nitrate ions in water. Compared with a Pd–Cu catalyst with TiO2 only as support (Pd–Cu/TiO2), which was proved to be active for this reaction in our previous study, Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 showed improved activity if TiO2–CeO2 contained an appropriate amount of ceria (Ti:Ce=18:1). Especially, the Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 (Ti:Ce=18:1) showed the initial nitrate reduction rate of 3.20mmol/min/gcat, eight times higher than that of Pd–Cu/TiO2 (0.41mmol/min/gcat). It was supposed that the improved activity of the catalyst was attributable to the reduced surface (oxygen vacancies) of the support and zero-valence states of the active metals (including the Pd–Cu alloy) in the catalyst. Keywords Nitrate reduction Water treatment TiO2–CeO2 Pd–Cu Bimetallic catalyst 1 Introduction Recently, the increasing levels of nitrate in source water have been receiving much attention because nitrate ions cause serious health hazards [1]. The World Health Organization and the European Community have proposed 25 and 50ppm, respectively, as allowable nitrate levels for drinking water [2,3]. Therefore, various physicochemical and biological treatments have been devised for nitrate removal from aqueous media, but each method suffers from technical and environmental problems, including secondary pollution [4,5]. Vorlop and Tacke suggested a catalytic reduction method based on the use of a (noble) metal-supported oxide as a catalyst and H2 gas as a reductant [6] as an active and environmentally benign method of nitrate removal. The active species of the catalyst, bimetallic species comprising a noble metal (Pd, Pt, Rh, or Ir) and Cu, is known to be particularly active in nitrate reduction [7,8]. It was proposed that nitrate reduction on the bimetallic catalysts occurs through a two-step mechanism, in which nitrate (NO3 −) is converted to nitrite (NO2 −) on metallic Cu by the hydrogen spilled over from the noble metal, and then the nitrite is reduced to N2 or ammonium (NH4 +) on the noble metal [7]. Among various noble-metal+copper combinations, Pd–Cu catalysts showed the highest activities in terms of NO3 − conversion and N2 selectivity [8]. For the best performance, it is important to maintain the metallic state of Cu (and Pd), because the entire reaction is initiated by the conversion of nitrate to nitrite, which is catalyzed through the redox cycle of Cu [9,10]. In our previous study, we selected commercial anatase titania (TiO2) as the support material for Pd–Cu [11] because it is known that reducible oxides such as TiO2 effectively promote nitrate conversion by attracting nitrate ions with their surface oxygen vacancies [12,13]. It was observed that the catalyst showed excellent activity (95% nitrate conversion, 53% N2 yield), which was attributed to the catalytic properties of the anatase TiO2 support: a high content of oxygen vacancies (high degree of surface reduction, i.e., Ti4+ →Ti3+) and strong interactions with supported metals to maintain Pd and Cu in their metallic states. Ceria (CeO2) is also a reducible oxide widely used in various industrial catalysts; it shows redox behavior between Ce3+ and Ce4+ under oxidizing and reducing conditions [14]. Based on their similarities, titania and ceria have been combined in a mixed oxide (TiO2–CeO2), which is found to be more effective than each single oxide in many applications as a reducible oxide support material. Andersson et al. [15] proved that the incorporation of Ti4+ into the CeO2 lattice decreases the formation energy and migration barrier of oxygen vacancies, inducing more reduced states (more Ce3+) on the CeO2 surface. Similarly, doping of Ce3+ on TiO2 induced more reduced states (more Ti3+) on the TiO2 surface [16]. Furthermore, it was reported that Pd–Cu/CeO2 showed high selectivity of nitrogen and it competed with Pd–Cu/TiO2 in overall nitrate reduction activities [17]. Therefore, the mixed oxide support, TiO2–CeO2 was anticipated to be a very useful support material for Pd–Cu catalysts for nitrate removal reactions. However, to the best of our knowledge, there has been no study of the application of Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts to nitrate reduction in water. In this study, we prepared Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts with different ceria contents, and investigated the effects of the ceria content on the physicochemical structure and nitrate removal activity of the catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The TiO2–CeO2 supports were synthesized using a coprecipitation method [18]. Titanium (III) sulfate (Aldrich, 99.9%) and cerium (IV) sulfate (Aldrich, 99%) were used as the Ti and Ce precursors, respectively. Stoichiometric amounts of the precursors were dissolved in deionized water (500mL). The pH of solution was adjusted to 10 using ammonium hydroxide (Aldrich, 30vol%) and the mixture was stirred for 24h at room temperature. The precipitates were filtered and washed repeatedly with deionized water. Then, the solids were dried at 90°C overnight and calcined at 600°C for 3h. Pd and Cu were impregnated on the TiO2–CeO2 support using deposition–precipitation method [19,20]. The TiO2–CeO2 support was immersed in HCl aqueous solution (500mL, 0.01M); then the stoichiometric amounts of palladium chloride (Aldrich, 99.5%) and copper chloride (Aldrich, 97%) were added simultaneously to the solution. After the precursors were completely dissolved, the slurry was heated to 70°C and Na2CO3 aqueous solution (1M) was slowly added to the solution with stirring until the pH of the slurry reached 10. The stirring was continued at 70°C for 4h. The whole procedures were performed under reflux condition. The catalysts were filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried at 90°C for 24h. The dried catalysts were calcined at 300°C for 6h. For the Pd–Cu/TiO2 catalyst, pure anatase TiO2 (Aldrich, 99.8%), which was calcined in air at 500°C for 4h, was used as the support and Pd–Cu was impregnated in the same way [11]. All the prepared catalysts were reduced in H2/N2 (10vol%) gas at 200°C for 2h before characterization or use in reaction tests. The abbreviations for, and chemical compositions of, the TiO2–CeO2 supports (TC) and Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts (PCTC) are presented in Table 1 . 2.2 Catalyst characterization The surface areas and pore volumes of the catalysts were determined using a Brunauer–Emmett–Teller analyzer (Micromeritics, ASAP 2010). The catalysts were degassed at 573K and 4mmHg, and then the N2 adsorption–desorption method was performed at 77K. The Ti:Ce molar ratios and Pd/Cu contents of the catalysts were determined using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES; Thermo Instrument, Polyscan 61E). X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterization was carried out using a D/MAX-2500 diffractometer (Rigaku) with Cu Kα1 radiation (λ =1.5406Å). The diffraction peaks were collected over the 2θ range 10°–80°, at a scanning rate of 1°/min. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy of CO adsorption was studied using a FTIR system (Perkin Elmer, Spectrum GX) attached with a diffuse reflection cell (Harrick, Praying Mantis). The spectra were collected in the range of 2250–1700cm−1 (resolution=4cm−1) on a MCT detector. The samples were pre-treated at 200°C under He flow (30mL/min) for 1h, followed by reduction using 10vol% H2/N2 (30mL/min) at 200°C for 1h. After reduction, the sample was cooled to 30°C under He flow (30mL/min) and then exposed to CO flow (30mL/min) at 30°C for 30min. Subsequently, the cell was purged with He for 30min, and the spectrum was acquired. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted using a PHI 5000 Versaprobe equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6eV). The core-level binding energies of Ti 2p, Ce 3d, Cu 2p, and Pd 3d were corrected with reference to the C 1s binding energy at 284.6eV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analysis was performed using a Tecnai G2 F30 instrument (200kV). The samples were suspended in ethanol, and then dispersed on the surface of a nickel grid. Elemental analysis of Pd and Cu was carried out using energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX). 2.3 Activity tests The nitrate-reduction reactions were carried out in a semi-batch reactor. The reactor was charged with deionized water (295mL) and then catalyst (0.15g) was added to the water. The reactor was purged with N2 gas (+99.999%) to remove air remaining in the reactor. 5mL of aqueous nitrate solution (2mM, KNO3) was added to the reactor (water) which was bubbled with pure H2 gas (90mL/min). The initial concentration of NO3 − was 124ppm. The activity tests were performed at 25°C and atmospheric pressure with flowing pure H2 gas (90mL/min) and stirring the reactor (water) at 700rpm. If necessary, CO2 gas was used as a pH buffer to improve catalytic activity. The concentrations of nitrate and nitrite ions were measured using high-performance liquid chromatography (Young-Lin, UV detector), and ammonium ions were determined using ion chromatography (Dionex, thermal conductivity detector). Catalytic activities were evaluated with nitrate conversion, nitrite and ammonium selectivities, and nitrogen yield, which were calculated as follows: Nitrate conversion , X N O 3 − ( % ) = C ( N O 3 − ) 0 − C ( N O 3 − ) f C ( N O 3 − ) 0 × 100 Nitrate selectivity , S N O 2 − ( % ) = C ( N O 2 − ) f C ( N O 3 − ) 0 − C ( N O 3 − ) f × 100 Ammonium selectivity , S N H 4 + ( % ) = C ( N H 4 + ) f C ( N O 3 − ) 0 − C ( N O 3 − ) f × 100 Nitrate yield ( % ) = X N O 3 − × ( 100 − S N O 2 − − S N H 4 + ) 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 BET and XRD analysis The BET properties of the TiO2–CeO2 supports (TC) and Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts (PCTC) are presented in Table 1. The BET areas of TC and PCTC were in the range of 60–88m2/g, both of which decreased with increasing the content of ceria. The pore volume did not follow this trend; it was the smallest in TC2 or PCTC2. Fig. 1 a and b shows XRD profiles of the TiO2–CeO2 supports and Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts, respectively. The TiO2–CeO2 supports contained both anatase and rutile TiO2 phases. With increasing ceria content (i.e., TC1→TC3), the titania peaks became weaker. Because of the different ionic radius between Ce4+ (0.092nm) and Ti4+ (0.065nm), the addition of Ce into the titania lattice inhibited the growth of TiO2 crystallites [14]. Diffraction peaks related to ceria appeared in TC2 and TC3. TC3 contained various ceria species (CeO2, Ce2O3, and Ce6O11). However, cerium titanate phases (Ce x Ti2–x O4) were not observed in the XRD patterns. In the XRD profiles of Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts, there were no peaks related to Pd and Cu (Fig. 1b), from which it was supposed that Pd and Cu species were highly dispersed on the supports. 3.2 CO DRIFT, XPS and HRTEM analysis The chemical states of Pd and Cu in the fresh PCTC catalysts were examined by DRIFT analysis of adsorbed carbon monoxide (Fig. 2 ). All the catalysts exhibited the IR absorption bands in 2010–1800cm−1, which represented the presence of bridge or multiple bonded CO on Pd0 [21]. The catalysts also exhibited two absorption bands around 2110 and 2090cm−1, which correspond to the linearly bonded CO on Cu0/Cu+ [22] and Pd0 [23,24], respectively. The 2090cm−1 peak was shifted downward from 2095 to 2089cm−1 with the decrease of ceria content in the TiO2–CeO2 support (i.e., PCTC3→PCTC1). The downward peak shift is related to the change in electron density of Pd d orbital, which might be induced by charge transfer between Pd and Cu, or Pd d → sp hybridization [25]. Similar phenomenon was observed in the carbon-monoxide IR spectra of several noble-metal alloys such as Pd–Au [26,27] and Pt–Cu [28]. From this, the peak shift could be an indication that Pd–Cu alloy is possibly formed on PCTC1. Fig. 3 shows the XPS analysis results for the Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts. In the Ti 2p XP spectra (Fig. 3a), PCTC1 exhibited the lowest binding energy, i.e., 456.9eV, which was very close to that of Ti3+ (456.8eV). The peak shifted toward Ti4+ as the Ce content of the catalyst increased (i.e., PCTC1→PCTC3), which implies that the content of reduced Ti ions (Ti3+) decreased with increasing Ce content. The Ce 3d spectra were very complex as a result of hybridization between Ce 4f and O 2p. The Ce 3d XPS peaks could be classified into two sets of spin-orbit multiplets: 3d5/2 (v) and 3d3/2 (u) [29]; these were applied to the Ce 3d spectra of the PCTC catalysts (Fig. 3b). The peaks marked v, v″, v′″, u, u″, and u′″ were assigned to Ce4+, and the other peaks (v 0, v′, u 0, and u′) were attributed to Ce3+ [30]. The Ce3+ concentrations in the catalysts were calculated based on the peak areas, using the equation Ce3+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) (%)=(v 0 + v′+ u 0 + u′)/∑(v + u) [31]; the results are presented in Table 2 . Among the catalysts, PCTC1 had the largest percentage of Ce3+ (40%). Similar to Ti, the content of reduced Ce ions (Ce3+) decreased with increasing Ce content in the catalyst (i.e., PCTC1→PCTC3). The formation of Ti3+ and Ce3+ are accompanied by oxygen vacancy formation [32,33], which implies that the PCTC1 surface is rich in oxygen vacancies. The different amount of oxygen vacancies depending on the Ce content was also evidenced by the O 1s XPS result (Fig. 3c). The O 1s XPS spectra of the PCTC catalysts could be deconvoluted into two (PCTC1) or three (PCTC2 and PCTC3) peaks. The peak located at the lowest binding energy (∼529.2eV) is ascribed to lattice oxygen of the metal oxides. The second peak (∼530.6eV) is assigned to chemisorbed oxygen and/or weakly bounded oxygen species on surface, and the third peak placed at the highest binding energy (∼532.1eV) is related to surface oxygen by hydroxyl species and/or adsorbed water species at the surface [14,34]; the peaks are denoted as a, b and c, respectively. Among the catalysts, O 1s spectrum of PCTC3 has higher binding energy components (b and c) than those of PCTC1 and PCTC2. The shift of O 1s peak toward high binding energy was similarly observed in other cases such as doping of heteroatom into single TiO2 or CeO2 [35,36]. Several researchers stated that the ratio of the chemisorbed oxygen peak area (i.e., the area of peak b, noted as A b) to total peaks area (i.e., A t = A a + A b + A c) is associated with the amount of oxygen vacancies formed on the catalyst surface [29,34]. In Table 2, the A b/A t ratios of the catalysts are compared, which shows that the A b/A t ratio was ordered as follows: PCTC1>PCTC2>PCTC3. It implies that the amount of oxygen vacancy increases as the Ce3+ concentration increases. Thus, it was concluded that PCTC1 contained the largest portion of oxygen vacancies among the catalysts. Fig. 4 a and b presents the Cu 2p and Pd 3d XP spectra of the Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts. The Cu 2p3/2 spectra (Fig. 4a) show that the three catalysts all contained alloyed Cu (i.e., Pd–Cu alloy) [37,38], which was paired with monometallic Cu [39,40] in PTCT1, but with ionic Cu in PCTC2 and PCTC3. The formation of Pd–Cu alloy could be supported by the CO DRIFT analysis results which were explained previously (Fig. 2). In the Pd 3d5/2 spectra, discrimination between Pd0 and Pd–Cu alloy was difficult because they have similar binding energies [37], although it is known that the core and valence levels of Pd in Pd–Cu alloys are slightly higher than those of pure Pd [25]. However, it was clear that the reduced Pd of PCTC1 was closer to metallic Pd or Pd–Cu alloy than those of PCTC2 and PCTC3 were. It is also worth mentioning that we observed in our previous study that Pd–Cu/TiO2 catalysts did not contain a Pd–Cu alloy [11]. To further verify the formation of Pd–Cu alloy on the PCTC catalysts, HRTEM analysis was carried out (Fig. 5 ). Fig. 5a presents the bright field HRTEM image of PCTC1, which shows that the supported particles were 2–5nm in size and dispersed well on the TiO2–CeO2 support. The high-magnification HRTEM images of PCTC1 (Fig. 5b and c) exhibited that the lattice d-spacing of supported particles were about 1.86Å and 1.29Å, which were close to the lattice spacing of (200) and (220) plane of Pd–Cu alloy, respectively [41,42]. The EDX analyses of PCTC catalysts (provided as Supplementary data) resulted in the coexistence of both Pd and Cu for the metal particles, which implies the particles are bimetallic (i.e., Pd–Cu alloy) [43]. In summary, the above results show that as the ceria content in the TiO2–CeO2 support decreased from 2:1 (PCTC3) to 18:1 (PCTC1): (1) the content (or percentage) of reduced Ti (Ti3+) and Ce (Ce3+) in the support increased, and (2) the reduced active metals became closer to zero-valence-state species such as monometallic Pd, Cu, and Pd–Cu alloy. 3.3 Reaction tests Fig. 6 shows the concentration profiles of nitrate, nitrite, and ammonium ions in the reaction tests using Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts (PCTC1, 2, and 3) under a pure H2 flow. The results of two Pd–Cu catalysts supported on ceria-free TiO2 (Pd–Cu/TiO2), one of which was a commercially obtained material (PCT500) [11] and the other of which was prepared with the method applied to the synthesis of TiO2–CeO2 (PCTC0), are plotted for comparison. The catalysts showed different initial nitrate consumption rate (Fig. 6a); the initial reaction rates were calculated as millimoles of nitrate ions consumed per liter (of water), per gram (of catalyst) during the first 3min (0–3min). The initial rate of PCTC1 (3.20mmol/min/gcat) was much faster than those for other TiO2–CeO2-supported catalysts (PCTC2 and PCTC3: 1.78 and 0.86mmol/min/gcat, respectively) and TiO2-supported catalysts (PCTC0 and PCT500: 1.90 and 0.41mmol/min/gcat, respectively). The plot of the concentration of nitrite with reaction time gave a volcano-shaped curve (Fig. 6b), which is typical of intermediate species in a serial reaction. The maximum concentration of nitrite was reached in a shorter time as the catalyst was changed to one giving a higher initial rate, and the highest nitrite concentration was observed in PCTC0 during the reaction. Considering the results for slow initial rate (PCT500) and high nitrite concentration (PCTC0), it was supposed that TiO2–CeO2 was more suitable support than TiO2 for the Pd–Cu active metal. The concentration of ammonium ions gradually increased with increasing reaction time (Fig. 6c). At the end of the reaction, the N2 yields for all the catalysts were very low (below 15%: not shown in the figure); this might be primarily because of the high pH (above 13) of the water, resulting from the generation of hydroxide ions during the reaction. Devadas et al. [44] claimed that the accumulation of nitrite and/or formation of ammonium ions are promoted as the pH of water increases. CO2 gas has been known as an efficient pH buffer which lowers pH and improves N2 yield for aqueous nitrate reduction [45]. Thus, we investigated the effect of CO2 addition on the nitrate reduction activity of PCTC1 catalyst, which resulted that the pH was dramatically lowered below 6 and N2 yield was increased up to 55% while lowering nitrite selectivity below 1% (Fig. 7 ). The best result was obtained with the gas composition of H2:CO2 =3:2 (90:60, in mL/min). Finally, we examined the recyclability of PCTC1 under the above reaction condition (H2 +CO2). Fig. 8 shows the changes of nitrate conversion and N2 yield over PCTC1 for four test runs (each run was continued for 100min). There was no change in catalytic activity of PCTC1 in the first two runs, but it starts to decline from the third run; the nitrate conversion and N2 yield also dropped to 84% and 45% after the fourth run, respectively. When compared with other Pd–Cu catalysts in terms of recyclability, PCTC1 was better than Pd–Cu/γ-Fe2O3 [46] and supported Pd–Cu/Al2O3 [47] catalysts, which were reported to decrease by 20–30% from first run under similar reaction conditions. It is generally understood that the decline of activity after repeated uses is related to the dissolution of Pd and Cu [2,46]. The recyclability test result indirectly proves that TC1 is better than γ-Fe2O3 and Al2O3 in stabilizing Pd–Cu active species during reaction. It was supposed that the comparatively higher activity of PCTC1 is related to its surface in a more reduced state, which was rich in Ti3+, Ce3+, and zero-valent active metals. The amounts of Ti3+ and Ce3+ are directly related to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies which promote the reaction by enriching nitrate ions on the catalyst surface. The zero-valence states of Pd and Cu are essential in the reaction mechanism, promoting hydrogen chemisorption/spillover as well as activation of the NO bonds of nitrate [48]. The Pd–Cu alloy is more effective in NO bond activation than monometallic Pd species are [48]. The interplay between zero-valent Pd–Cu and oxygen vacancies (on TiO2–CeO2) would promote NO bond dissociation, resulting in the improved nitrate-reduction activity. 4 Conclusions Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 (Ti:Ce=18:1) was more active than Pd–Cu/TiO2 catalysts in the reduction of nitrate ions in water. The TiO2–CeO2 supports were a mixture of titania and ceria; an appropriate ceria content (Ti:Ce=18:1) was crucial for the catalytic activity, which was associated with the contents of surface Ti3+, Ce3+, and zero-valent Pd and Cu. The use of TiO2–CeO2 as a support for Pd–Cu led to the generation of a Pd–Cu alloy, which is more active for NO activation than pure Pd metal is. Therefore, it could be concluded that the addition of an appropriate level of ceria to the Pd–Cu/TiO2 catalyst is beneficial to its nitrate-reduction activity. coredata.dc:description: Pd–Cu supported on TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxides (Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2) were tested for the reduction of nitrate ions in water. Compared with a Pd–Cu catalyst with TiO2 only as support (Pd–Cu/TiO2), which was proved to be active for this reaction in our previous study, Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 showed improved activity if TiO2–CeO2 contained an appropriate amount of ceria (Ti:Ce=18:1). Especially, the Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 (Ti:Ce=18:1) showed the initial nitrate reduction rate of 3.20mmol/min/gcat, eight times higher than that of Pd–Cu/TiO2 (0.41mmol/min/gcat). It was supposed that the improved activity of the catalyst was attributable to the reduced surface (oxygen vacancies) of the support and zero-valence states of the active metals (including the Pd–Cu alloy) in the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Pd–Cu bimetallic catalysts supported on TiO2–CeO2 mixed oxides for aqueous nitrate reduction by hydrogen
